newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: BAT Cambodia unveils $16 million plant upgrade.
newsitem.headline: BAT Cambodia unveils $16 million plant upgrade.

text.p: British-American Tobacco (BAT) Cambodia Ltd executives on Friday announced a $16-million factory upgrade aimed at increasing its share of the lucrative Cambodian market.

At a ceremony unveiling the plans, co-Premier Prince Norodom Ranariddh told BAT officials and dignataries that the new leaf processing plant, high-speed machines and office facilities would further promote Cambodia's largely agrarian economy.

"BAT's investment in the cigarette industry not only has resulted in job creation...it has also assisted Cambodian farmers," Ranariddh said. He said BAT has supplied seeds and technical assistance to farmers.

Corporate Affairs Manager Martin Riordan said the new facilities, expected to be completed within 12 months, would not increase capacity or the company's 730-person work force but improve quality and thus cut into the import market.
About half of Cambodia's smokers consume international brands, according to market analysts.
"At this stage, we're...trying to improve the local brands and help them to be more popular, which will take the strain off imports," said Riordan.
There is intense competition for Cambodia's smokers, with 100 brands on the market here, according to industry analysts.
Riordan said BAT alone produces six billion local-brand cigarettes a year -- a third of the local market -- in a country of 10.5 million people.

BAT returned to Cambodia last June after a 22-year absence as lead stakeholder in a joint venture with formerly state-owned Cambodian Tobacco Co and Singapore-based SUTL Corporation, which assists in cigarette marketing and distribution.
